The weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem on a Euclidean Jordan algebra

Xiaoni Chi    M. Seetharama Gowda    Jiyuan Tao
(Received: date / Accepted: date)
Abstract

A weighted complementarity problem (wCP) is to find a pair of vectors belonging to the intersection of a manifold and a cone such that the product of the vectors in a certain algebra equals a given weight vector. If the weight vector is zero, we get a complementarity problem. Examples of such problems include the Fisher market equilibrium problem and the linear programming and weighted centering problem. In this paper we consider the weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem (wHLCP) in the setting of Euclidean Jordan algebras and establish some existence and uniqueness results. For a pair of linear transformations on a Euclidean Jordan algebra, we introduce the concepts of 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}, 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}, and 𝐏𝐏{\bf P} properties and discuss the solvability of wHCLPs under nonzero (topological) degree conditions. A uniqueness result is stated in the setting of ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}. We show how our results naturally lead to interior point systems.

Keywords:
Weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem Euclidean Jordan algebra Degree 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair

90C30

1 Introduction

Introduced in potra1 , a weighted complementarity problem (wCP) is to find a pair of vectors (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) belonging to the intersection of a manifold with a cone such that their product in a certain (Euclidean Jordan) algebra equals a given weight vector w𝑤w. When w𝑤w is the zero vector, wCP becomes a complementarity problem (CP). To elaborate, consider a Euclidean Jordan algebra (V,∘,⟨⋅,⋅⟩)𝑉⋅⋅(V,\circ,\langle\cdot,\cdot\rangle) with symmetric cone V+subscript𝑉V_{+} faraut-koranyi . Given a map F:V×V×ℝl→V×ℝl:𝐹→𝑉𝑉superscriptℝ𝑙𝑉superscriptℝ𝑙F:V\times V\times\mathbb{R}^{l}\rightarrow V\times\mathbb{R}^{l} and a weight vector w∈V+𝑤subscript𝑉w\in V_{+}, wCP is to find (x,y)∈V×V𝑥𝑦𝑉𝑉(x,y)\in V\times V such that for some u𝑢u,

x∈V+,y∈V+,x∘y=w,F​(x,y,u)=0.formulae-sequence𝑥subscript𝑉𝑦subscript𝑉𝑥𝑦𝑤𝐹𝑥𝑦𝑢0\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{l}x\in V_{+},\ y\in V_{+},\\ x\circ y=w,\\ F(x,y,u)=0.\end{array} (4)

Deferring this general problem for a future study, in potra1 and potra2 , Potra studies affine wCP on the (Euclidean Jordan) algebra ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} with several examples and results. Given matrices A,B∈ℝ(n+m)×n𝐴𝐵superscriptℝ𝑛𝑚𝑛A,B\in\mathbb{R}^{(n+m)\times n}, C∈ℝ(n+m)×m𝐶superscriptℝ𝑛𝑚𝑚C\in\mathbb{R}^{(n+m)\times m}, a weight vector w∈ℝ+n𝑤subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛w\in\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}, and q∈ℝn+m𝑞superscriptℝ𝑛𝑚q\in\mathbb{R}^{n+m}, the weighted mixed horizontal linear complementarity problem considered in potra1 , potra2 is to find (x,y,z)∈ℝn×ℝn×ℝm𝑥𝑦𝑧superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑚(x,y,z)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{n}\times\mathbb{R}^{m} such that

x≥0,y≥0,x∗y=w,A​x+B​y+C​z=q,formulae-sequence𝑥0𝑦0∗𝑥𝑦𝑤𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝐶𝑧𝑞\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{l}x\geq 0,\ y\geq 0,\\ x\ast y=w,\\ Ax+By+Cz=q,\end{array} (8)

where x∗y𝑥𝑦x*y denotes the Hadamard (= componentwise) product of vectors x𝑥x and y𝑦y. Here, C𝐶C is assumed to be of full column rank and so, with a suitable change of variables, one could transform (see Section 2 in potra2 ) the above problem to an equivalent affine wCP where C𝐶C becomes vacuous and A𝐴A and B𝐵B are square. It is shown in potra1 that the Fisher market equilibrium problem eisenberg-gale ,ye and the linear programming and weighted centering problem anstricher can be formulated in the form (8), where the triple (A,B,C)𝐴𝐵𝐶(A,B,C) satisfies a certain monotonicity condition. In potra1 , Potra presented and analyzed two interior-point methods for solving such monotone affine wCPs. Subsequently, replacing ‘monotone’ conditions by ‘row and column sufficient’ conditions, Potra potra2 described several theoretical results and a corrector-predictor interior-point method for its numerical solution.

We note that weighted complementarity problems were studied much earlier in connection with interior point methods. For example, in kojima et al , Kojima et al showed that if (continuous) f:ℝn→ℝn:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛f:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n} is a uniform P-function, that is, there exists some γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 such that

max1≤i≤n⁡(xi−yi)​(fi​(x)−fi​(y))≥γ​‖x−y‖2​(for all​x,y∈ℝ+n),subscript1𝑖𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑓𝑖𝑥subscript𝑓𝑖𝑦𝛾superscriptnorm𝑥𝑦2for all𝑥𝑦subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛\max_{1\leq i\leq n}(x_{i}-y_{i})\Big{(}f_{i}(x)-f_{i}(y)\Big{)}\geq\gamma||x-y||^{2}\,\,\,(\mbox{for all}\,\,x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}),

then the mapping f^:ℝ+n×ℝ+n→ℝ+n×ℝn:^𝑓→subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛\widehat{f}:\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{n} is a homeomorphism, where

f^​(x,y)=[x∗yy−f​(x)].^𝑓𝑥𝑦delimited-[]𝑥𝑦𝑦𝑓𝑥\widehat{f}(x,y)=\left[\begin{array}[]{c}x*y\\ y-f(x)\end{array}\right].

In this situation, the following weighted nonlinear complementarity problem has a unique solution for each w∈ℝ+n𝑤subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛w\in\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+} and q∈ℝn𝑞superscriptℝ𝑛q\in\mathbb{R}^{n}:

x≥0,y≥0,x∗y=w,y=f​(x)+q.formulae-sequence𝑥0𝑦0∗𝑥𝑦𝑤𝑦𝑓𝑥𝑞\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{l}x\geq 0,\ y\geq 0,\\ x\ast y=w,\\ y=f(x)+q.\end{array} (12)

Another work that specifically looks at the general wCP (4) is by Yoshise yoshise . In this work, under certain‘monotonicity and injectivity’ assumptions, it is shown that the map (x,y,u)→(x∘y,F​(x,y,u))→𝑥𝑦𝑢𝑥𝑦𝐹𝑥𝑦𝑢(x,y,u)\rightarrow\Big{(}x\circ y,F(x,y,u)\Big{)} is a homeomorphism on a certain subset of V+×V+×ℝlsubscript𝑉subscript𝑉superscriptℝ𝑙V_{+}\times V_{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{l}, leading to the solvability of wCP, see Theorem 3.10 and Corollary 4.4 in yoshise .

Our objective in this paper is to consider the following affine wCP in the setting of Euclidean Jordan algebras. Given two linear transformations A𝐴A and B𝐵B on a Euclidean Jordan algebra V𝑉V, a weight vector w∈V+𝑤subscript𝑉w\in V_{+}, and q∈V𝑞𝑉q\in V, the weighted horizontal linear complementarity problem wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q) is to find (x,y)∈V×V𝑥𝑦𝑉𝑉(x,y)\in V\times V such that

x≥0,y≥0,x∘y=w,A​x+B​y=q,formulae-sequence𝑥0𝑦0𝑥𝑦𝑤𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑞\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{l}x\geq 0,\ y\geq 0,\\ x\circ y=w,\\ Ax+By=q,\end{array} (16)

where x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0 means that x∈V+𝑥subscript𝑉x\in V_{+}, etc. If w=0𝑤0w=0, the above problem reduces to the (symmetric cone) horizontal linear complementarity problem on V𝑉V, denoted by HLCP(A,B,q)𝐴𝐵𝑞(A,B,q). If w=0𝑤0w=0, A=I𝐴𝐼A=I, and B=−M𝐵𝑀B=-M, HLCP(A,B,q)𝐴𝐵𝑞(A,B,q) reduces to the (symmetric cone) linear complementarity problem LCP(M,q)𝑀𝑞(M,q) on V𝑉V. In particular, when V=ℝn𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛V=\mathbb{R}^{n}, this reduces to the standard linear complementarity problem.

Our analysis differs from Potra’s potra1 , potra2 in several ways. First, our setting is that of a general Euclidean Jordan algebra, instead of ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}. Second, instead of the ‘monotone/sufficient’ conditions, we rely on the 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0} property (that is commonly used in the LCP literature) coupled with a nonzero degree condition of a certain map associated with wHLCP. Third, instead of using the optimization methodology, we rely on the degree theoretic tools. Our analysis also differs from that of Yoshise yoshise where results were proved under certain ‘monotonicity and injectivity’ conditions.

In this paper, we establish some basic existence/uniqueness results about wHLCPs. Generalizing the LCP concept of a degree of an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-matrix, we introduce the concept of degree of an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair of linear transformations in the setting of Euclidean Jordan algebras. Assuming that this degree is nonzero for the pair {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\}, we show that wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q) has a nonempty compact solution set for every (w,q)∈V+×V.𝑤𝑞subscript𝑉𝑉(w,q)\in V_{+}\times V. This conclusion, in particular, will allow us to say that

  • ∙∙\bullet

    the map Γ:V+×V+→V+×V:Γ→subscript𝑉subscript𝑉subscript𝑉𝑉\Gamma:V_{+}\times V_{+}\rightarrow V_{+}\times V given by Γ​(x,y)=(x∘y,A​x+B​y)Γ𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦\Gamma(x,y)=\Big{(}x\circ y,Ax+By\Big{)} is surjective and

  • ∙∙\bullet

    when w>0𝑤0w>0 (that is, w∈int​(V+)𝑤intsubscript𝑉w\in\mbox{int}(V_{+})), the ‘interior point system’

    x>0,y>0,x∘y=w,and​A​x+B​y=qformulae-sequence𝑥0formulae-sequence𝑦0formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑤and𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑞x>0,\,y>0,\,\,x\circ y=w,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,Ax+By=q

    has a nonempty compact solution set.

The result about the interior point system appears to be new even in the setting of standard LCPs.

We also introduce the concept of a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pair and show that when V=ℝn𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛V=\mathbb{R}^{n}, wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q) has a unique solution for every (w,q)∈ℝ+n×ℝn𝑤𝑞subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛(w,q)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{n}.

The organization of our paper is as follows. In Section 2, we cover some basic material. In Section 3, we introduce the concepts of 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0} and 𝐑𝐑{\bf R} pairs and define the degree of an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair. Section 4 covers the main result of the paper describing the solvability of wHLCP. While Section 5 deals with the solution set behavior, Sections 6 and 7 cover 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pairs and address uniqueness issues.

2 Preliminaries

Our next key result will be used to show that the min and the Fischer-Burmeister maps are ‘homotopic’. This will allow us to replace the Fischer-Burmeister map by the ‘simpler’ min map in our main solution analysis.

Proposition 2

Let x,y∈V𝑥𝑦𝑉x,y\in V and 0≤t≤10𝑡10\leq t\leq 1. Then,

We end this subsection by quoting a well-known determinantal formula.

Proposition 3

A similar statement can be made about linear transformations.

2.1 Degree theory

We employ degree theoretic arguments to prove our existence results. All necessary results concerning degree theory are given in facchinei-pang (specifically Proposition 2.1.3); see also, lloyd , ortega-rheinboldt . Here is a brief summary. Suppose ΩΩ\Omega is a bounded open set in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}, g:Ω¯→ℝn:𝑔→¯Ωsuperscriptℝ𝑛g:\overline{\Omega}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n} is continuous and p∉g​(∂Ω)𝑝𝑔Ωp\not\in g(\partial\Omega), where Ω¯¯Ω\overline{\Omega} and ∂ΩΩ\partial\Omega denote, respectively, the closure and boundary of Ω.Ω\Omega. Then the degree of g𝑔g over ΩΩ\Omega with respect to p𝑝p is defined; it is an integer and will be denoted by deg(g,Ω,p)𝑔Ω𝑝(g,\Omega,p). When this degree is nonzero, the equation g​(x)=p𝑔𝑥𝑝g(x)=p has a solution in Ω.Ω\Omega. Suppose g​(x)=p𝑔𝑥𝑝g(x)=p has a unique solution, say, x∗superscript𝑥x^{*} in Ω.Ω\Omega. Then deg(g,Ω′,p)𝑔superscriptΩ′𝑝(g,\Omega^{\prime},p), which equals deg(g,Ω′,g​(x∗))𝑔superscriptΩ′𝑔superscript𝑥(g,\Omega^{\prime},g(x^{*})), is constant over all bounded open sets Ω′superscriptΩ′\Omega^{\prime} containing x∗superscript𝑥x^{*} and contained in Ω.Ω\Omega. This common degree is called the (topological) index of g𝑔g at x∗superscript𝑥x^{*}; it will be denoted by ind(g,x∗)𝑔superscript𝑥(g,x^{*}). In particular, if g:ℝn→ℝn:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛g:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n} is a continuous map such that g​(x)=0⇔x=0⇔𝑔𝑥0𝑥0g(x)=0\Leftrightarrow x=0, then for any bounded open set containing 0, we have

ind​(g,0)=deg​(g,Ω,0);ind𝑔0deg𝑔Ω0\textrm{ind}(g,0)=\textrm{deg}(g,\Omega,0);

moreover, when g𝑔g is the identity map, ind​(g,0)=1.ind𝑔01\textrm{ind}(g,0)=1.

Let H​(x,t):ℝn×[0,1]→ℝn:𝐻𝑥𝑡→superscriptℝ𝑛01superscriptℝ𝑛H(x,t):\mathbb{R}^{n}\times[0,1]\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n} be continuous (in which case, we say that H𝐻H is a homotopy). Suppose that for some bounded open set ΩΩ\Omega in ℝn,superscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}, 0∉H​(∂Ω,t)0𝐻Ω𝑡0\not\in H(\partial\Omega,t) for all t∈[0,1].𝑡01t\in[0,1]. Then, the homotopy invariance property of degree says that deg​(H​(⋅,t),Ω,0)deg𝐻⋅𝑡Ω0\textrm{deg}\Big{(}H(\cdot,t),\Omega,0\Big{)} is independent of t.𝑡t. In particular, if the zero set

{x:H​(x,t)=0​for​some​t∈[0,1]}conditional-set𝑥𝐻𝑥𝑡0forsome𝑡01\displaystyle\Big{\{}x:H(x,t)=0\ \textrm{for}\ \textrm{some}\ t\in[0,1]\Big{\}}

is bounded, then for any bounded open set ΩΩ\Omega in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} containing this zero set, we have

deg​(H​(⋅,1),Ω,0)=deg​(H​(⋅,0),Ω,0).deg𝐻⋅1Ω0deg𝐻⋅0Ω0\displaystyle\textrm{deg}\Big{(}H(\cdot,1),\Omega,0\Big{)}=\textrm{deg}\Big{(}H(\cdot,0),\Omega,0\Big{)}.

Note: All degree theory concepts and results are also valid over any finite dimensional real Hilbert space (such as V𝑉V or V×V𝑉𝑉V\times V) instead of ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}.

2.2 A normalization argument

To show that the zero set of a map or a system of equations is bounded, we frequently employ the so-called normalization argument. Here, a certain sequence of vectors (with their norms going to infinity) is normalized to yield a unit vector that violates a given criteria. We illustrate this in the following result, which will be used later.

Proposition 4

Let A𝐴A and B𝐵B two linear transformations on V𝑉V and p∈V𝑝𝑉p\in V. Suppose that

3 The degree of an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair

In the setting of V=ℝn𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛V=\mathbb{R}^{n}, the concepts of LCP-degree of a matrix and HLCP-degree of a pair of matrices are useful in describing the existence and stability of solutions, see gowda-degree and sznajder . In what follows, we extend these to Euclidean Jordan algebras. Consider linear transformations M𝑀M, A𝐴A, and B𝐵B on (a general algebra) V𝑉V and recall that

HLCP​(A,B,q):=wHLCP​(A,B,0,q)andLCP​(M,q):=HLCP​(I,−M,q).formulae-sequenceassignHLCP𝐴𝐵𝑞wHLCP𝐴𝐵0𝑞andassignLCP𝑀𝑞HLCP𝐼𝑀𝑞\mathrm{HLCP}(A,B,q):=\mathrm{wHLCP}(A,B,0,q)\quad\mbox{and}\quad\mathrm{LCP}(M,q):=\mathrm{HLCP}(I,-M,q).

In view of Item (i​i​i)𝑖𝑖𝑖(iii) in Proposition 1, HLCP​(A,B,q)HLCP𝐴𝐵𝑞\mathrm{HLCP}(A,B,q) is equivalent to finding (x,y)∈V×V𝑥𝑦𝑉𝑉(x,y)\in V\times V such that

x⊓y=0,A​x+B​y=q,square-intersection𝑥𝑦0𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑞\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{c}x\sqcap y=0,\\ Ax+By=q,\end{array} (22)

and LCP​(M,q)LCP𝑀𝑞\mathrm{LCP}(M,q) is equivalent to finding an x∈V𝑥𝑉x\in V such that

x⊓(M​x+q)=0.square-intersection𝑥𝑀𝑥𝑞0x\sqcap(Mx+q)=0.

We say that M𝑀M has the 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0} property on V𝑉V if zero is the only solution of LCP(M,0)𝑀0(M,0), or equivalently,

x⊓M​x=0⇔x=0.⇔square-intersection𝑥𝑀𝑥0𝑥0x\sqcap Mx=0\Leftrightarrow x=0.

When this condition holds, for any bounded open set ΩΩ\Omega in V𝑉V that contains zero, deg(θ,Ω,0)𝜃Ω0(\theta,\Omega,0) is well defined, where

θ​(x):=x⊓M​x.assign𝜃𝑥square-intersection𝑥𝑀𝑥\theta(x):=x\sqcap Mx.

This common value – which is ind(θ,0)𝜃0(\theta,0)– defines the LCP-degree of M, denoted by deg⁡(M)degree𝑀\deg(M). We now extend this concept to a pair of transformations.

Definition 1

The pair {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is said to be an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair if zero is the only solution of HLCP(A,B,0)𝐴𝐵0(A,B,0). This means that

Our first result extends Corollary 5.2.6 in sznajder from ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} to a general Euclidean Jordan algebra.

In the standard LCP theory, 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}-matrices cottle et al form an important subclass of matrices for which LCP-degree is nonzero. (We note that there are other matrices, such as 𝐍𝐍{\bf N}-matrices of first category satisfying this property gowda-degree .) Recall that M𝑀M is an 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}-matrix (in the standard LCP setting) if there is some d>0𝑑0d>0 in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} such that zero is the only vector that solves the problems LCP(M,0)𝑀0(M,0) and LCP(M,d)𝑀𝑑(M,d). We now consider a generalization.

Definition 2

Let A𝐴A and B𝐵B be two linear transformations on V𝑉V. We say that {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is an 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}-pair if it is an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair and there exists p∈V𝑝𝑉p\in V such that

  • (a)𝑎(a)

    HLCP(A,B,p)𝐴𝐵𝑝(A,B,p) has a unique solution, say, (x¯,y¯)¯𝑥¯𝑦(\overline{x},\overline{y}),

  • (b)𝑏(b)

    x¯+y¯>0¯𝑥¯𝑦0\overline{x}+\overline{y}>0, and

  • (c)𝑐(c)

    The derivative of G𝐺G at (x¯,y¯)¯𝑥¯𝑦(\overline{x},\overline{y}) is nonsingular, where

4 The main existence result

We now discuss the solvability of wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q). We recall that (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) is a solution of wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q) if and only if it is a solution of the system

x+y−x2+y2+2​w=0,A​x+B​y−q=0.𝑥𝑦superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦22𝑤0𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑞0\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{c}x+y-\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}+2w}=0,\\ Ax+By-q=0.\end{array}

deg​(F​(⋅,1),Ω,0)=deg​(F​(⋅,0),Ω,0)=deg​(H​(⋅,1),Ω,0)=deg​(H​(⋅,0),Ω,0)deg𝐹⋅1Ω0deg𝐹⋅0Ω0deg𝐻⋅1Ω0deg𝐻⋅0Ω0\textrm{deg}\Big{(}F(\cdot,1),\Omega,0\Big{)}=\textrm{deg}\Big{(}F(\cdot,0),\Omega,0\Big{)}=\textrm{deg}\Big{(}H(\cdot,1),\Omega,0\Big{)}=\textrm{deg}\Big{(}H(\cdot,0),\Omega,0\Big{)}

and

deg​(H​(⋅,0),Ω,0)=deg​(Θ,Ω,0)=ind​(Θ,0)=deg⁡(A,B).deg𝐻⋅0Ω0degΘΩ0indΘ0degree𝐴𝐵\textrm{deg}\Big{(}H(\cdot,0),\Omega,0\Big{)}=\textrm{deg}\Big{(}\Theta,\Omega,0\Big{)}=\mathrm{ind}(\Theta,0)=\deg(A,B).

deg​(F​(⋅,1),Ω,0)≠0.deg𝐹⋅1Ω00\textrm{deg}\Big{(}F(\cdot,1),\Omega,0\Big{)}\neq 0.

This means that the equation F​(z,1)=0𝐹𝑧10F(z,1)=0 has a zero in ΩΩ\Omega proving the existence of a solution of wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q). As all zeros of F​(⋅,1)𝐹⋅1F(\cdot,1) are in the bounded set ΩΩ\Omega and the solution set of wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q) is clearly closed, we see nonemptyness and compactness of this solution set. This completes the proof. ∎

Motivated by interior point methods, we consider the case w>0𝑤0w>0. First, we make a simple observation:

[x≥0,y≥0,and​x∘y>0]⟹x>0​and​y>0.⟹delimited-[]formulae-sequence𝑥0formulae-sequence𝑦0and𝑥𝑦0𝑥0and𝑦0\Big{[}x\geq 0,\,y\geq 0,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,x\circ y>0\Big{]}\Longrightarrow x>0\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,y>0.

This follows from Item (i​v)𝑖𝑣(iv), Lemma 2.6 in yoshise . Here is a short/different proof. Let x≥0𝑥0x\geq 0, y≥0𝑦0y\geq 0 and x∘y=w>0𝑥𝑦𝑤0x\circ y=w>0. Suppose x≯0not-greater-than𝑥0x\not>0 so that zero is an eigenvalue of x𝑥x. This means that there is a primitive idempotent e1subscript𝑒1e_{1} (which belongs to the Jordan frame that appears in the spectral decomposition of x𝑥x) such that x∘e1=0𝑥subscript𝑒10x\circ e_{1}=0. But then, 0<⟨w,e1⟩=⟨x∘y,e1⟩=⟨y,x∘e1⟩=00𝑤subscript𝑒1𝑥𝑦subscript𝑒1𝑦𝑥subscript𝑒100<\langle w,e_{1}\rangle=\langle x\circ y,e_{1}\rangle=\langle y,x\circ e_{1}\rangle=0, is a contradiction. Hence, x>0𝑥0x>0 and, similarly, y>0𝑦0y>0.

Corollary 1

Let {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} be an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair with deg⁡(A,B)degree𝐴𝐵\deg(A,B) nonzero. Suppose w>0𝑤0w>0. Then for any q∈V𝑞𝑉q\in V, the following ‘interior point system’ has a nonempty compact solution set:

x>0,y>0,x∘y=w,and​A​x+B​y=q.formulae-sequence𝑥0formulae-sequence𝑦0formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑤and𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦𝑞x>0,\,\,y>0,\,\,x\circ y=w,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,Ax+By=q.

We now specialize the above two results for a single linear transformation.

Corollary 2

Let M𝑀M be a linear transformation on V𝑉V. Suppose that M𝑀M has the 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0} property and deg⁡(M)degree𝑀\deg(M) is nonzero. Then, for all (w,q)∈V+×V𝑤𝑞subscript𝑉𝑉(w,q)\in V_{+}\times V, the weighted linear complementarity problem

x≥0,y≥0,x∘y=w,and​y=M​x+qformulae-sequence𝑥0formulae-sequence𝑦0formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑤and𝑦𝑀𝑥𝑞x\geq 0,\,\,y\geq 0,\,\,x\circ y=w,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,y=Mx+q

has a nonempty compact solution set. In particular, when w>0𝑤0w>0, for any q∈V𝑞𝑉q\in V, the ‘interior point system’

x>0,y>0,x∘y=w,and​y=M​x+qformulae-sequence𝑥0formulae-sequence𝑦0formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦𝑤and𝑦𝑀𝑥𝑞x>0,\,\,y>0,\,\,x\circ y=w,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,y=Mx+q

has a nonempty compact solution set.

Remarks. In the standard LCP literature, the solvability and uniqueness issues of interior point systems are usually addressed for special types of 𝐏0subscript𝐏0{\bf P}_{0}-matrices (e.g., 𝐏∗subscript𝐏{\bf P}_{*}-matrices), see kojima book , Lemma 4.3 and Theorem 4.4. In this regard, the above result appears to be new even in the case of V=ℝn𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛V=\mathbb{R}^{n}, as it holds for numerous types of non 𝐏0subscript𝐏0{\bf P}_{0}-matrices such as strictly copositive matrices, 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}-matrices, and 𝐍𝐍{\bf N}-matrices of first category cottle et al .

5 The solution set behavior

Fixing the pair {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\}, we let SOL​(w,q)SOL𝑤𝑞\textrm{SOL}(w,q) denote the solution set of
wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q). The following result describes the behavior of the map (w,q)↦SOL​(w,q)maps-to𝑤𝑞SOL𝑤𝑞(w,q)\mapsto\textrm{SOL}(w,q).

Theorem 5.1

Suppose {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is an 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pair with deg⁡(A,B)degree𝐴𝐵\deg(A,B) nonzero. Then, the following statements hold:

    The solution map (w,q)↦SOL​(w,q)maps-to𝑤𝑞SOL𝑤𝑞(w,q)\mapsto\mathrm{SOL}(w,q) from V+×Vsubscript𝑉𝑉V_{+}\times V to V+×V+subscript𝑉subscript𝑉V_{+}\times V_{+} is upper semicontinuous.

  • (b)𝑏(b)

    Let wk≥0subscript𝑤𝑘0w_{k}\geq 0 for all k=1,2,…,𝑘12…k=1,2,\ldots, and wk→w→subscript𝑤𝑘𝑤w_{k}\rightarrow w.   • (c)𝑐(c)

    Let w>0𝑤0w>0, tk↓0↓subscript𝑡𝑘0t_{k}\downarrow 0, and (xk,yk)∈SOL​(tk​w,q)subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑦𝑘SOLsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑤𝑞(x_{k},y_{k})\in\mathrm{SOL}(t_{k}\,w,q) for all k𝑘k. Proof. (a)𝑎(a) We fix (w∗,q∗)∈V+×Vsuperscript𝑤superscript𝑞subscript𝑉𝑉(w^{*},q^{*})\in V_{+}\times V and let ΩΩ\Omega be any open set in V×V𝑉𝑉V\times V containing SOL(w∗,q∗)superscript𝑤superscript𝑞(w^{*},q^{*}). (b)𝑏(b) Under the stated assumptions, (wk,q)→(w,q)→subscript𝑤𝑘𝑞𝑤𝑞(w_{k},q)\rightarrow(w,q). 6 P-pairs over V𝑉V

A linear transformation M𝑀M on V𝑉V is said to be a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformation gowda-sznajder-tao if

x​and​M​x​operator commutex∘M​x≤0}⇒x=0.⇒cases𝑥and𝑀𝑥operator commute𝑥𝑀𝑥0𝑥0\left.\begin{array}[]{r}x\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,Mx\,\,\mbox{operator commute}\\ x\circ Mx\leq 0\end{array}\right\}\Rightarrow x=0.

𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformations are generalizations of 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-matrices. An important example of 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformations appears in dynamical systems: the Lyapunov transformation X↦A​X+X​ATmaps-to𝑋𝐴𝑋𝑋superscript𝐴𝑇X\mapsto AX+XA^{T} on the Euclidean Jordan algebra of n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n real symmetric matrices is a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformation if and only if the (real square) A𝐴A is positive stable. See gowda-sznajder-tao for properties of 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformations and further examples. We now extend this notion to a pair of transformations.

Definition 3

A pair of linear transformations {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is said to be a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pair over V𝑉V if

x​and​y​operator commutex∘y≤0A​x+B​y=0}⇒(x,y)=(0,0).⇒cases𝑥and𝑦operator commute𝑥𝑦0𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦0𝑥𝑦00\left.\begin{array}[]{r}x\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,y\,\,\mbox{operator commute}\\ x\circ y\leq 0\\ Ax+By=0\end{array}\right\}\Rightarrow(x,y)=(0,0).

Below, we collect some properties of such pairs.

Proposition 7

Suppose {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pair. Then, the following statements hold.

  • (a)𝑎(a)

    A𝐴A and B𝐵B are invertible.

  • (b)𝑏(b)

    −B−1​Asuperscript𝐵1𝐴-B^{-1}A and −A−1​Bsuperscript𝐴1𝐵-A^{-1}B are 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformations.

  • (c)𝑐(c)

    {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is an 𝐑𝐑{\bf R}-pair.

  • (d)𝑑(d)

    For all (w,q)∈V+×V𝑤𝑞subscript𝑉𝑉(w,q)\in V_{+}\times V, wHLCP​(A,B,w,q)wHLCP𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞\mathrm{wHLCP}(A,B,w,q) has a nonempty compact solution set.

Proof. (a)𝑎(a) If A​x=0𝐴𝑥0Ax=0 for some x𝑥x, then

[xand  0operator commute,x∘0=0,Ax+B0=0]⇒(x,0)=(0,0).\Big{[}\,x\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,0\,\,\mbox{operator commute},\,\,x\circ 0=0,\,Ax+B0=0\Big{]}\Rightarrow(x,0)=(0,0).

Hence (x,y)=(0,0)𝑥𝑦00(x,y)=(0,0) and so x=0.𝑥0x=0. Thus, −B−1​Asuperscript𝐵1𝐴-B^{-1}A is a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformation. Similarly, −A−1​Bsuperscript𝐴1𝐵-A^{-1}B is also a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformation.

Let (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y) be any solution of HLCP(A,B,p)𝐴𝐵𝑝(A,B,p) so that x​and​y​operator commute𝑥and𝑦operator commutex\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,y\,\,\mbox{operator commute}, x,y≥0𝑥𝑦0x,y\geq 0, and x∘y=0𝑥𝑦0x\circ y=0. Example 3 Let V=𝒮n𝑉superscript𝒮𝑛V={\cal S}^{n}, the Euclidean Jordan algebra of all n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n real symmetric matrices with ⟨X,Y⟩:=t​r​a​c​e​(X​Y)assign𝑋𝑌𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑐𝑒𝑋𝑌\langle X,Y\rangle:=trace(XY) and X∘Y:=X​Y+Y​Xassign𝑋𝑌𝑋𝑌𝑌𝑋X\circ Y:=XY+YX. Here, 𝒮+nsubscriptsuperscript𝒮𝑛{\cal S}^{n}_{+} is the ‘semidefinite cone’ consisting of positive semidefinite matrices in 𝒮nsuperscript𝒮𝑛{\cal S}^{n}. We write X⪰0succeeds-or-equals𝑋0X\succeq 0 and X≻0succeeds𝑋0X\succ 0, respectively, to denote elements of V+subscript𝑉V_{+} and its interior. Let A𝐴A be an n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n real matrix which is positive stable (which means that every eigenvalue of A𝐴A has positive real part). Then, the Lyapunov transformation X↦A​X+X​ATmaps-to𝑋𝐴𝑋𝑋superscript𝐴𝑇X\mapsto AX+XA^{T} is a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-transformation on 𝒮nsuperscript𝒮𝑛{\cal S}^{n} gowda-sznajder-tao . Consequently, for any W≻0succeeds𝑊0W\succ 0, the following system has a solution:

X≻0,Y≻0,X∘Y=W,and​Y=A​X+X​AT.formulae-sequencesucceeds𝑋0formulae-sequencesucceeds𝑌0formulae-sequence𝑋𝑌𝑊and𝑌𝐴𝑋𝑋superscript𝐴𝑇X\succ 0,\,\,Y\succ 0,\,\,X\circ Y=W,\,\,\mbox{and}\,\,Y=AX+XA^{T}.

While the existence of an X≻0succeeds𝑋0X\succ 0 with A​X+X​AT≻0succeeds𝐴𝑋𝑋superscript𝐴𝑇0AX+XA^{T}\succ 0 is already covered in the Lyapunov theory of dynamical systems, what is new here is that such an X𝑋X can be found satisfying an additional condition X∘(A​X+X​AT)=W𝑋𝐴𝑋𝑋superscript𝐴𝑇𝑊X\circ(AX+XA^{T})=W where W≻0succeeds𝑊0W\succ 0 is arbitrary! One can make statements similar to the above for the Stein transformation X↦X−B​X​BTmaps-to𝑋𝑋𝐵𝑋superscript𝐵𝑇X\mapsto X-BXB^{T}, where B𝐵B is an n×n𝑛𝑛n\times n real Schur stable matrix (which means that every eigenvalue of B𝐵B has absolute value less than one) gowda-sznajder-tao .

7 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pairs over ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}

We now consider V=ℝn𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛V=\mathbb{R}^{n} and prove a uniqueness result.

Theorem 7.1

Let V=ℝn𝑉superscriptℝ𝑛V=\mathbb{R}^{n}. Then, the following statements are equivalent:

  • (a)𝑎(a)

    {A,B}𝐴𝐵\{A,B\} is a 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pair.

  • (b)𝑏(b)

    wHLCP​(A,B,w,q)wHLCP𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞\mathrm{wHLCP}(A,B,w,q) has a unique solution for every (w,q)∈ℝ+n×ℝn𝑤𝑞subscriptsuperscriptℝ𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛(w,q)\in\mathbb{R}^{n}_{+}\times\mathbb{R}^{n}.

  • (c)

    HLCP​(A,B,q)HLCP𝐴𝐵𝑞\mathrm{HLCP}(A,B,q) has a unique solution for every q∈ℝn.𝑞superscriptℝ𝑛q\in\mathbb{R}^{n}.

Proof (a)⇒(b)⇒𝑎𝑏(a)\Rightarrow(b): The solvability of wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q) has been addressed in the previous result. We now prove uniqueness. Suppose that (x1,y1)subscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1(x_{1},y_{1}) and (x2,y2)subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2(x_{2},y_{2}) are any two solutions of wHLCP(A,B,w,q)𝐴𝐵𝑤𝑞(A,B,w,q), i.e.,

As w≥0𝑤0w\geq 0, let

α:={i:wi>0}andβ:={i:wi=0}.formulae-sequenceassign𝛼conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖0andassign𝛽conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖0\alpha:=\{i:w_{i}>0\}\quad\mbox{and}\quad\beta:=\{i:w_{i}=0\}.

Then,

(x1∗y1)i=(x2∗y2)i=wi>0,∀i∈α,(x1∗y1)i=(x2∗y2)i=wi=0,∀i∈β.formulae-sequencesubscript∗subscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1𝑖subscript∗subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖0for-all𝑖𝛼formulae-sequencesubscript∗subscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1𝑖subscript∗subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖0for-all𝑖𝛽\displaystyle\begin{array}[]{c}(x_{1}\ast y_{1})_{i}=(x_{2}\ast y_{2})_{i}=w_{i}>0,\quad\forall\,i\in\alpha,\\ (x_{1}\ast y_{1})_{i}=(x_{2}\ast y_{2})_{i}=w_{i}=0,\quad\forall\,i\in\beta.\end{array}

(b)⇒(c)::⇒𝑏𝑐absent(b)\Rightarrow(c): This is obvious by taking w=0𝑤0w=0.
(c)⇒(a)::⇒𝑐𝑎absent(c)\Rightarrow(a): Suppose (x,y)≠(0,0)𝑥𝑦00(x,y)\neq(0,0) with x∘y≤0𝑥𝑦0x\circ y\leq 0 and A​x+B​y=0𝐴𝑥𝐵𝑦0Ax+By=0. For q:=A​x++B​y+=A​x−+B​y−assign𝑞𝐴superscript𝑥𝐵superscript𝑦𝐴superscript𝑥𝐵superscript𝑦q:=Ax^{+}+By^{+}=Ax^{-}+By^{-}, we see that (x+,y+)superscript𝑥superscript𝑦(x^{+},y^{+}) and (x−,y−)superscript𝑥superscript𝑦(x^{-},y^{-}) are two distinct solutions of HLCP(A,B,q)𝐴𝐵𝑞(A,B,q). This contradicts condition (c)𝑐(c). ∎

We remark that such a uniqueness result may not prevail over general Euclidean Jordan algebras even for P-transformations, see the remarks following Theorem 14 in gowda-sznajder-tao .
The above result, especially Item (c)𝑐(c), allows us to connect 𝐏𝐏{\bf P}-pairs to the so-called 𝐖𝐖{\bf W} property for a pair of matrices, see sznajder-gowda .

Concluding Remarks. In this paper, we have presented some existence and uniqueness results for weighted horizontal linear complementarity problems over Euclidean Jordan algebras. These are established for 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pairs of linear transformations satisfying a (nonzero) degree condition. The novelty here is the use of ‘weighted’ Fischer-Burmeister map and degree theory techniques. We hope to consider applications, algorithms, and non 𝐑0subscript𝐑0{\bf R}_{0}-pairs in a future study.
